summary: This document is a chain of emails from September 2019 between Assistant United States Attorneys and other personnel regarding the taint review process of electronic materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence. The correspondence expresses concern that the volume of extracted documents (about 20,000) seems low given the number of devices seized and discusses coordination with agents and Epstein's defense attorneys.

persons.name: Ori
persons.context: Primary correspondent in the email chain, coordinating the taint review of seized Epstein materials, communicating with agents and Epstein's defense attorneys.

persons.name: Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the investigation; materials were seized from his Manhattan residence.

connections.description: Ori, an AUSA, is involved in the legal process (taint review) of materials seized from Epstein's residence as part of the investigation.

events.title: Seized Materials Made Available
events.description: Electronic materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence were made available for review.

events.title: Taint Review Volume Reported
events.description: An email reports that the taint review yielded about 20,000 documents, with many being non-user files like Adobe instructions.

events.title: Concern Over Document Volume
events.description: Prosecutors express concern that 20,000 documents is 'exceedingly low' given the seizure of approximately 38 computers/electronic storage devices and 55 CDs, and request cross-referencing information.

keyFacts: Prosecutors were conducting a 'taint review' of electronic materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence, which were made available on September 10, 2019.
The initial yield from the taint review was reported as about 20,000 documents, but prosecutors found this number 'exceedingly low' given the volume of devices seized.
Seizure records indicated approximately 38 computers/electronic storage devices and 55 CDs were taken from Epstein's residence.
Epstein's defense attorneys had provided search terms to be run as part of the taint review process, indicating coordination between prosecution and defense on the review.
The correspondence shows internal prosecution concerns about the completeness of the data extraction from the seized devices.
